title: McLeod's Daughters is back! Channel Nine CONFIRMS a reunion
text:
McLeod's Daughters, Australia's most popular and successful rural drama, is making a comeback for a one-night-only live event.

The 'McLeod's Daughters Bush Christmas Reunion' will take place on Thursday, December 5 in Lismore City Hall.

Major cast members are returning for the special event, including Bridie Carter, Lisa Chappell, Simmone Jade McKinnon, Aaron Jeffery, Myles Pollard and Zoe Naylor.

Comeback: McLeod's Daughters, Australia's most popular and successful rural drama, is making a comeback for a one-night-only live event. Pictured: the cast of McLeod's Daughters

The actors will be live on stage for fans to hear personal anecdotes and stories from the Drovers Run family, participate in a Q&A session, and view and discuss their favourite scenes.

There will be limited-edition and official McLeod's Daughters merchandise designed specifically for the event, as well as an opportunity to purchase a limited number of tickets for either the private backstage VIP tour or an intimate Golden Supper with the cast.

McLeod's Daughters, which followed the lives of five women running a cattle station in the outback, aired for eight seasons on Channel Nine between 2001 and 2009.

Big announcement! McLeod's Daughters cast members spoke about the reunion special on the Today show on Monday

It was one of the most successful shows on Australian TV, garnering an average of 1.51 million viewers during its first season.

Two years ago, reports surfaced that Channel Nine was considering a reboot.

In July 2017, a network spokesman told News.com.au: 'We are talking to [co-creator] Posie Graeme-Evans about how we could tackle it.

Festive treat! The 'McLeod's Daughters Bush Christmas Reunion' will take place on Thursday, December 5 in Lismore City Hall. Pictured: a scene from McLeod's Daughters

'We know how much everybody loves McLeod's Daughters, it's an important part of our heritage. Nothing is commissioned, or set in stone.'

However, those plans were scrapped a few months later, reportedly due to 'creative differences' between Nine and the Graeme-Evans.
